body:
Loading a module (e.g. `module load py-flake8`) should not generate extraneous output otherwise modules become very difficult to use inside scripts because the `lmod` output has to be filtered out of the real output.

Right now, this happens:

```
[hartzelg@rpbuchop001 spack-20161212]$ module load py-flake8
Autoloading py-mccabe/0.5.2
Autoloading python/2.7.12
Autoloading bzip2/1.0.6
Autoloading ncurses/6.0
Autoloading zlib/1.2.8
Autoloading openssl/1.0.2j
Autoloading sqlite/3.8.5
Autoloading readline/6.3
Autoloading py-enum34/1.1.6
Autoloading py-pyflakes/1.2.3
Autoloading py-pycodestyle/2.0.0
Autoloading py-configparser/3.5.0
[hartzelg@rpbuchop001 spack-20161212]$
```

Loading a module that does not contain any autoloads is happily silent.

```
[hartzelg@rpbuchop001 spack-20161212]$ module load sqlite
[hartzelg@rpbuchop001 spack-20161212]$
```

The "Autoloading..." message comes from bits like this in the generated modulefiles.

```
if not isloaded("py-enum34/1.1.6") then
    LmodMessage("Autoloading py-enum34/1.1.6")
    load("py-enum34/1.1.6")
end
```

This (for Lmod) is in turn generated by this bit in `lib/spack/spack/modules.py`.

```
    autoload_format = ('if not isloaded("{module_file}") then\n'
                       '    LmodMessage("Autoloading {module_file}")\n'
                       '    load("{module_file}")\n'
                       'end\n\n')
```

I'd like to remove the message from both the tcl and Lmod autoload formats.

Is there someone that feels strongly that autoloaded modules should be noisy?
title: Modules that autoload other modules should do it quietly.
